publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 06:59

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.physdesc: (77 boxes)
did.abstract: The collection consists of tankas, which are Buddhist scrolls or fabric temple banners, chiefly Tibetan, but also Nepalese, Bhutanese, Indian and Chinese, which bear religious images, circa 1600-circa 1950. Some tankas also bear inscriptions on their versos.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired from various sources. For further information consult entries for individual tankas in the guide to the collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Tanka Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Tanka Collection. General Collection of Books and Manuscripts, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: All of the deity names are expressed in accordance with the Library of Congress Authority File.

Descriptions of individual items derive chiefly from catalog cards created by Wesley E. Needham (Yale 1954 Hon. M.A.H.) at the time of acquisition, as well as from a survey of the material completed by Paul A. Draghi in June 1994.

bioghist.head: Tankas
bioghist.p: Tankas, also known as thangkas, are hanging scrolls or fabric temple banners that consist of a painted picture panels (called mélong in Tibetan, which means 'mirror'), usually depicting buddhas, mandalas, or great practitioners, which are sewn into or bordered by a textile mountings. Tankas are intended to serve as records of, and guides for, contemplative experiences and visualizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of 77 tankas, chiefly Tibetan, but also Nepalese, Bhutanese, Indian and Chinese, which bear religious images, circa 1600-circa 1950. Some tankas also bear inscriptions on their versos.

Divinities represented in the collection include Akṣobhya, Amitābha, Amitāyus, Avalokiteśvara, Bardo Thodol deities, Bhaiṣajyaguru, Dorje Shugden, Garwai Nagpo Damchen, Hayagrīva, Mahākāla, Palden Lhamo, Prajñāpāramitā, Rāhula, Sitātapatrā, Tārā, Vajrabhairava, Vajrapāṇi, Vajrasattva, Vajrayoginī, Vasudhārā, and Viśrāvaṇa.

Buddhist practitioners with portraits in the collection include Gautama Buddha, his arhats (disciples), Kloṅ-chen-pa Dri-med-'od-zer, Lobsang Chökyi Gyaltsen, Mi-la-ras-pa, Ṅag-dbaṅ-blo-bzaṅ-rgya-mtsho, Padma Sambhava, Tsoṅ-kha-pa Blo-bzaṅ-grags-pa, and Yungtön Dorjepel, as well as unidentified Karmapa abbots and an unidentified Sa-skya-pa lama.
Portrayals of inanimate objects and locations include srid-pa-ho (astrological divination charts), a srid-pa'i-'khor-lo (wheel of life), rgyan-tshogs (offerings), a stupa and a mandala.
Identified artists in the collection consist of Tsewang Norbu, an artist active in Darjeeling, India, circa 1865, as well as Rin-zin (or Rig-zin), a artist active in Sikkim, India, circa 1950.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: I. Identified Creators, circa 1865-circa 1950. II. Identified Subjects, circa 1600-circa 1950.

did.physdesc: (8 paintings)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is organized alphabetically by the artist, followed by groups of tankas by an unidentified Tibetan and Nepalese artists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tankas created by identified Indian artists or attributed to unidentified Tibetan and Nepalese artists.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Rin-zin (or Rig-zin) was an artist active in Sikkim, India, circa 1950.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 63 x 49 cm. bordered with silk brocade 130 x 97 cm. in a frame.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Mañjuśrī is a bodhisattva associated with transcendent wisdom.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Publisher Elliott Beach Macrae (1900-1968) was given the tanka by Tashi Namgyal (1893-1963), the Maharaja Chogyal of Sikkim, circa 1950.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Sikkimese watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Mañjuśrī, accompanied by a white Tārā with seven eyes and Viśrāvaṇa, the chief of the Four Heavenly Kings. The figures are reportedly modeled after the Macrae family.
Inscriptions in Tibetan on verso.
The tanka includes a silk cover and ribbons.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Tsewang Norbu was an artist in Darjeeling, India.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 104 x 74 cm. bordered with silk 104 x 73 cm.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Gautama Buddha (circa 563 BCE-483 BCE), also known as Śākyamuni, was a spiritual teacher from ancient India who founded Buddhism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Gautama Buddha surrounded by nine figures. The painting also depicts the male and female patron on the painting in Sanskrit expressed in phonetic Tibetan, Bhalaram Norbu and Bhanavati Drolma.
Inscription in Tibetan on the verso, which venerates Gautama Buddha, the patrons, and the artist.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Two tankas created by an unidentified Tibetan artist based on Jātakas, a body of literature native to India concerning the previous births (jāti) of the Gautama Buddha.

did.unittitle: Tanka of Gautama Buddha and scenes from the Vessantara Jātaka
did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 65.5 x 40.0 cm. bordered with silk 134 x 76 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Gautama Buddha surrounded by scenes from "Vessantara Jātaka," In the story a compassionate prince gives away everything he owns, including his wife and children, thereby displaying the virtue of perfect charity.
The tanka includes a silk cover.

did.unittitle: Tanka of Gautama Buddha and scenes from the Ruru Deer Jātaka
did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 65.5 x 39.0 cm. bordered with silk 134 x 76 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Gautama Buddha surrounded by scenes from "The Ruru Deer Jātaka," In the story the Ruru Deer saves man, who then betrays the deer, but the deer survives and teaches.
The tanka includes a silk cover.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Four tankas created by an unidentified northern Nepalese artist.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased by Joseph F. Weiler in Nepal. Gifts of Joseph F. Weiler and Eliza Weiler, 1983.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 57 x 39 cm. mounted on cotton 87 x 63 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A watercolor painting on cotton that depicts a red Amitāyus seated on a multicolored lotus accompanied by three smaller figures above and six human figures below in Nepalese dress and holding black umbrellas.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 54 x 41 cm. mounted on cotton 93 x 79 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Avalokiteśvara seated on a pink lotus accompanied by smaller figures, as well as Amitābha above and Padma Sambhav below.
Inscription in Tibetan on the verso. Consecrated by a lama to address an illness.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 77.5 x 46.5 cm. mounted on cotton 108 x 67 cm

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A watercolor painting on cotton that depicts the 42 Peaceful Deities of Bardo with Samantabhadra in a rainbow framed circle accompanied by human figures below in Nepalese dress and holding black umbrellas.
Inscription in Tibetan on the verso. Nine of the inscriptions are consecrations of the divinities on the recto.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 21 x 16 cm. mounted on cotton and silk 58 x 42 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Padma Sambhava seated on a lotus throne.

did.physdesc: (69 paintings)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is organized alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tankas created by unidentified artists from Tibet, Nepal, Bhutan, and China of identified subjects.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Akṣobhya is one of the Five Wisdom Buddhas, a product of the Adi-Buddha, who represents consciousness as an aspect of reality.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 65.0 x 44.5 cm. borderd with silk brocade 114 x 71 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased in Nepal by Ann Rohrer in 1968. Gift of Ann Rohrer, 1976.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Nepalese watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Akṣobhya surrounded by 516 miniature emanations of himself. All of the figures are outlined in red on gold.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Amitābha, also known as "The Buddha of Infinite Light," is a celestial buddha known for his longevity and the deep awareness of individualities.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 61.5 x 41.0 cm. mounted on silk brocade 107 x 58 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Amitābha seated on a lotus throne presiding over Sukhāvatī, his celestial realm, surrounded by eight bodhisattvas and telve smaller buddhas and divinities, and behind a lake with two babies upon a lotus.
The tanka includes a silk cover and ribbons.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 65 x 46 cm. mounted on silk brocade 112 x 71 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An eastern Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Amitābha surrounded by miniature figures.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Amitāyus is also used for the Sambhogakāya aspect of Amitābha, particularly associated with longevity.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 70.0 x 45.5 bordered with silk brocade 118 x 72 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: A watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Amitāyus, a deity associated with longevity, surrounded with 144 miniature emanations of himself.
Inscription in Tibetan on the verso.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Arhats, also known as Sthaviras, were sixteen individuals selected by Gautama Buddha from among his disciples and to remain in the world and protect the Dharma for as long as beings are capable of benefitting from the teachings. The sixteen arhats are usually depicted in tankas accompanied by their two attendants, Hva Shang and Upasaka Dharmatala, as well as by the Four Great Kings.

did.unittitle: Tanka of two arhats accompanied by Upasaka Dharmatala
did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 63 x 42 cm. bordered with silk brocade 132 x 81 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts two of the sixteen arhats, the original followers of the Buddha, accompanied by Upasaka Dharmatala, a patron of the Dharma, attendant of the sixteen arhats and a manifestation of Avalokiteśvara.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 70 x 46 bordered with silk brocade 144 x 74 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred from the Yale University Art Gallery, 1960. Former Art Gallery No. 1951.51.52.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts two of the sixteen arhats, the original followers of the Buddha.
The painting is one of a set of nine paintings and is marked "Right-two" in Tibetan on its verso.
Inscriptions in Tibetan on the verso.
The tanka includes a silk cover and ribbons.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Avalokiteśvara is a bodhisattva that embodies the speech of all the buddhas and incarnation of their compassion.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 91.5 x 60.0 cm. mounted on silk in a frame 101 x 67 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Orson L. St. John, 1985.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan or Chinese watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Avalokiteśvara with a eleven heads and eight arms standing on a lotus.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 76 x 48 cm. bordered with silk brocade 133 x 76 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Avalokiteśvara accompanied by celestial scenes and divinities, as well as a figure of a Tibetan king.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 65 x 42 cm. bordered with silk brocade 130 x 84 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Tibet House, New Delhi, India, 1966.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An eastern Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Avalokiteśvara accompanied by eight smaller figures.
Inscriptions in Tibetan on the verso.
The tanka includes a silk cover and ribbons.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 57.0 x 39.5 cm. bordered with silk brocade 115 x 70 cm

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An eastern Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts a white Avalokiteśvara with four arms seated on a pink lotus below Gautama Buddha, Vajrapāṇi, and Tsoṅ-kha-pa Blo-bzaṅ-grags-pa with two disciples, as well as above Manjushri, a green Tārā, and Vajrapāṇi.
Inscriptions in Tibetan on the verso.
The tanka includes a silk cover.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 69 x 49 cm. bordered with silk brocade 122 x 78 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased in Nepal by Ann Rohrer in 1968. Gift of Ann Rohrer, 1976.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A southern Tibetan or Bhutanese watercolor painting on cottton that depicts Avalokiteśvara with four arms and accompanied by numerous smaller figures.
Inscriptions in Tibetan on the verso.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 45 x 31 cm. mounted on silk brocade 85 x 57 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased in Nepal by Ann Rohrer in 1968. Gift of Ann Rohrer, 1976.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cottton that depicts Avalokiteśvara with four arms and accompanied by Manjushri and Vajrapāṇi.
Inscriptions in Tibetan on verso.
The tanka includes a silk cover.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Bardo Thodol, also known as the Tibetan Book of the Dead, is a text used in Tibetan Buddhism to guide one through the experiences that the consciousness has after death, during the interval between death and the next rebirth. The first portion of the ritual is dedicated to the epiphany of the peaceful and wrathful bardo deities.

did.unittitle: Tanka of the 58 Wrathful Deities of Bardo
did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 74 x 47 cm. bordered with silk brocade 123 x 78 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts the 58 Wrathful Deities of Bardo.
Inscriptions in Tibetan on verso.

did.unittitle: Tanka of the 42 Peaceful Deities of Bardo
did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 74 x 54 cm. bordered with silk brocade 125 x 85 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts the 42 Peaceful Deities of Bardo accompanied by other figures and some inscriptions.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Bhaiṣajyaguru, also known as the Medicine Buddha, is the buddha of healing and medicine in Mahāyāna Buddhism. He is described as a doctor who cures suffering using the medicine of his teachings.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 51 x 34 cm. bordered with silk brocade 101 x 69 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Bhaiṣajyaguru accompanied by seven emanations of himself and posited above a depiction of Mahākāla.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Dorje Shugden, also known as Dolgyal Shugden, a deity in the Dge-lugs-pa school of Buddhism, and regarded as a Dharma Protector or "guardian angel."

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 36.5 x 29.0 cm. bordered with silk brocade 85 x 60 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Dorje Shugden below three lamas and two deities and above three deities, as well as flanked by three smaller figures.
Inscriptions in Tibetan on verso.
The tanka includes a silk cover and ribbons.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Garwai Nagpo Damchen, also known as the Blacksmith, is the main attendant to Vajrasadhu, and the oath bound worldly protector of the Nyingma School.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 39.5 x 25.5 cm. bordered with silk brocade 78 x 51 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Garwai Nagpo Damchen holding a vajra hammer in his right hand, wearing a hat, and riding a goat. He is below Tsoṅ-kha-pa Blo-bzaṅ-grags-pa and two of his disciples.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 94.5 x 62.5 cm. in a frame 101 x 67 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Orson L. St. John, 1985.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan or Chinese watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Gautama Buddha seated on a lotus accompanied by two lamas, four arhats, and several divinities, including Yama and Yami.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 63.5 x 35.5 cm. bordered with silk brocade 105 x 55 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Gautama Buddha escorted by two bodhisattvas and blessing a lama above a scene of the lama accompanied by Sarasvatī, a guardian deity who upholds the teachings of Gautama Buddha by offering protection and assistance to practitioners.
The tanka includes a silk cover.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: gold ink on silk on rice paper 119 x 68 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Chinese gold ink painting on black silk that depicts Gautama Buddha accompanied by smaller figures.
Writing on the upper recto of the painting in Chinese, Manchu, Mongolian, and Tibetan.
Inscription in French on verso.

did.unittitle: Tanka of Gautama Buddha with eight arhats and two attendants
did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton 98 x 63 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan or Chinese watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Gautama Buddha accompanied by eight arhats and two attendants, probably Hva Shang and Upasaka Dharmatala. The tanka has painted borders that simulate silk brocade.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 70 x 45 cm. bordered with silk 101 x 58 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Colonel Eric Foster Storm, 1963.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A western Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Gautama Buddha accompanied by smaller figures, including a monkey. Several panels in the image contain inscriptions in cursive Tibetan script.
Depiction of a stupa on the verso.

did.unittitle: Tanka of Gautama Buddha, disciples, and the Thirty-five Buddhas of Confession
did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 62.0 x 41.5 cm. bordered with silk brocade 90 x 65 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A western Tibetan or Nepalese watercolor painting on cotton, probably by an amateur artist that depicts Gautama Buddha seated on a lotus throne flanked by two of his chief disciples, Sāriputta and Moggallāna, and surrounded by the Thirty-five Buddhas of Confession.
The tanka includes a silk cover

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 94 x 64 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Tibet House, New Delhi, India, 1966.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton by a refugee painter that depicts Gautama Buddha accompanied by two buddha figures and two arhats.
Inscriptions in Tibetan on verso.

did.unittitle: Tanka of Gautama Buddha, disciples, and the Thirty-five Buddhas of Confession
did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 65.0 x 47.5 cm., unmounted and unbordered

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A western Tibetan or Nepalese watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Gautama Buddha surrounded by the Thirty-five Buddhas of Confession.
Inscriptions in Tibetan on verso.

did.unittitle: Gautama Buddha and Scenes from Jātakas

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Jātakas are a body of literature native to India concerning the previous births (jāti) of the Gautama Buddha.

did.unittitle: Tanka of Gautama Buddha and scenes from the Starving Tigress Jātaka
did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 60 x 41 cm. bordered with silk brocade 135 x 81 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred from the Yale University Divinity School Library, 1960. Gift of Orville Anderson Petty (Yale Ph.D. 1915, Hon. D.D. 1919).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Gautama Buddha surrounded by scenes from "The Starving Tigress Jātaka." In the story a bodhisattva sees a starving tigress about to eat her own cubs, and the bodhisattva offers her his own body.
Inscription in Tibetan on verso describes the position of the tanka in relation to other tankas.
The tanka includes a silk cover and ribbons.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Guhyasamāja is a blue-black Akṣobhyavajra, a form of Akṣobhya.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 61 x 42 cm. bordered with silk brocade 112 x 58.5 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Nepalese watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Guhyasamāja with a dark blue body, six arms, and three faces and in union with his consort as Sparshavajrā, as well as accompanied by forty-five figures.
The tanka includes a silk cover.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Hayagrīva is a fierce horse-faced deity who is powerful in driving off unconverted demonic forces.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 47 x 34 cm. bordered with silk brocade 102 x 66 cm

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton with embroidery that depicts Hayagrīva surrounded by emanations of himself and other figures.
Inscription in Tibetan on verso.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 74 x 52 cm. bordered with brocade 152 x 102 cm.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Bowles was given the tanka by the King of Nepal, Tribhuvan Bir Bickrum Shah, circa 1951-1953.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton with embroidery that depicts Hayagrīva surrounded by thirty-six figures. The painting is mounted on brocade that depicts dragons.
Inscriptions in Tibetan on verso.
The tanka includes a silk cover and ribbons.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Karmapa is the head of the Karma Kagyu, the largest sub-school of the Kagyupa, itself one of the four major schools of Tibetan Buddhism.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 63 x 42 cm. bordered with silk brocade 122 x 84 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Orson L. St. John, 1985.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A watercolor painting on cotton that depicts an unidentified Karmapa abbot wearing a red hat and seated, as well as accompanied by smaller figures, including a lama and protective divinities. Consecrated on the verso by a lama.
Depiction of a stupa and inscriptions in Tibetan on verso.
Accompanied with an envelope from Hotel Mount Everest, Darjeeling, India, with notes about the tanka.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 23.0 x 18.5 cm. mounted on silk brocade 48 x 40 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Orson L. St. John, 1985.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A watercolor painting on cotton that depicts an unidentified Karmapa abbot wearing a red hat and seated, as well as accompanied by smaller figures of two monks and three protective divinities seated on a horse, elephant, and a mythological creature.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Kloṅ-chen-pa Dri-med-'od-zer (1308-1363), also known as Longchenpa or Longchen Rabjampa, was a major teacher in the Nyingma school of Tibetan Buddhism.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 61.0 x 35.5 cm. bordered with silk brocade 118 x 74 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Kloṅ-chen-pa Dri-med-'od-zer or Chos Kyi Rgya Mtsho sitting on a cushion below Amitāyus and two protective divinities and above Vajrapāṇi and dharmapalas.
Separate inscriptions on verso of painting identify it as Kloṅ-chen-pa Dri-med-'od-zer and Chos Kyi Rgya Mtsho
The tanka includes a silk cover and ribbons.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Lobsang Chökyi Gyaltsen (1570-1662) was the fourth Panchen Lama of Tibet, and the first accorded the title during his lifetime.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 64 x 37 cm. bordered with silk brocade 107 x 58 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Lobsang Chökyi Gyaltsen wearing yellow and seated on cushions with smaller figures of protective divinities, ten lamas, and Güshi Khan (1582-1655), a Khoshut prince and leader of the Khoshut Khanate.
The tanka includes a silk cover.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Mahākāla is a dharmapala in Vajrayana Buddhism.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 44.5 x 34.0 cm. mounted on silk brocade 92 x 58 cm

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Mahākāla with a dark blue body, three heads, and six arms, with ornaments made of human skulls, and accompanied by thirty-eight figures. Consecrated by a lama on the verso with an om-ah-hum and the red hand prints of the lama and the patron.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 39 x 25 cm. bordered with silk brocade 71 x 42 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Mahākāla with four faces and four arms, with ornaments made of human skulls.
Inscription in Tibetan on verso.
The tanka includes a silk cover.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Mandala is a Sanskrit word that means "circle". In Buddhist religious traditions their sacred art often takes a mandala form, which is a square with four gates containing a circle with a center point.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 68.5 x 49.0 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts a mandala consisting of a square with four gates containing a circle with a center point. Miniature figures are depicted outside of the enclosure.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Mi-la-ras-pa (circa 1052-circa 1135), also known as Jetsun Milarepa, was a Tibetan yogi and poet, as well as a founder of the Kagyü school of Tibetan Buddhism.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 111 x 68 cm. mounted on bordered with silk 119 x 76 cm. in a frame.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Mi-la-ras-pa surrounded by previous hierarchs in the Kagyü school and smaller replicas of himself.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Ṅag-dbaṅ-blo-bzaṅ-rgya-mtsho (1617-1682) was the Fifth Dalai Lama and a political and religious leader in seventeenth-century Tibet.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 65 x 50 cm. bordered with silk 87 x 79 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Nepalese watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Ṅag-dbaṅ-blo-bzaṅ-rgya-mtsho, probably in Potala Palace and accompanied by musicians, with other human figures in the foreground.
Inscription in Tibetan on verso.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Padma Sambhava (circa 717-circa 762), also known as Guru Rinpoche or Lopon Rinpoche, was a guru from Oddiyana (modern Swat, Pakistan) credited with introducing Vajrayana Buddhism to Bhutan and Tibet in the eighth century.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 37 x 23 cm. bordered with silk 72 x 40 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Orson L. St. John, 1985.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A western Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Padma Sambhava seated on a lotus blossom below three smaller protective divinities of Amitābha, Amitāyus, and Tārā, as well as above two smaller figures of Nyingma disciples.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 34 x 28 cm. bordered with silk brocade 80 x 61 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A western Tibetan or Nepalese watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Padma Sambhava with two female consorts, Mandarava and Yeshe Tsogyal.
Inscriptions in Tibetan on verso.
The tanka includes a silk cover.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Palden Lhamo is a female deity who protects the teachings of Gautama Buddha in the Gelug school of Tibetan Buddhism, as well as the principal Protectress of Tibet.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 48.0 x 35.5 cm. bordered with silk brocade 74 x 50 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Palden Lhamo crossing a sea of blood riding side-saddle on a white mule. Above her are Tsoṅ-kha-pa Blo-bzaṅ-grags-pa and a Panchen Lama.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 41 x 28 cm. bordered with silk brocade 83 x 55 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Palden Lhamo crossing a sea of blood riding side-saddle on a white mule. Above her are Tsoṅ-kha-pa Blo-bzaṅ-grags-pa and two of his disciples. Below her is a mounted figure.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 59 x 48 cm. in a frame 61 x 51 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred from the Yale University Art Gallery, 1960. Former Art Gallery No. 1952.40.23.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Palden Lhamo surrounded by miniature figures.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Prajñāpāramitā is a concept of buddhist transcendental wisdom perfection is often personified as a bodhisattvadevi (female bodhisattva)

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 13 x 10 cm. bordered with silk 28 x 26 cm. in a frame.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: An example of a tsakli (also "tsakalis"), a Tibetan miniature painting, normally produced as thematic groups or sets, which are used in rituals. A tsakli can also be placed in a portable shrine or box (Tibetan "gau") and carried as a device giving protection to the traveller or pilgrim who carries this box around the neck or on a shoulder strap.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Prajñāpāramitā.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Rāhula is a Tibetan protector deity based on the Indian deity Rahula, an ancient Indian god, a demi-god, of the cosmos, related to the eclipse of the sun, moon and other planets.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 56 x 41 cm. bordered with silk brocade 117 x 76 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Nepalese or Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Rāhula surrounded by eight figures.
The tanka includes a silk cover.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Rgyan-tshogs, also known as an assembly of offerings, are pictorial representations of a spectrum of peaceful and wrathful attributes and offerings to the deities.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 49.6 x 37.5 cm., unmounted and unbordered

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts a Rgyan-Tshogs that consists of skulls, bones, flayed human hides, dogs sheep, yaks, and horses.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Sa-skya-pa school is one of four major schools of Tibetan Buddhism.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 60 x 45 cm. bordered with silk brocade 116 x 61 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An eastern Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts an unidentified Sa-skya-pa lama sitting on a cushion below figures and two guardian divinities and above three protective divinities.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Sitātapatrā is the Goddess of the White Parasol and protector against supernatural danger.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 67 x 45 cm. bordered with silk brocade 106 x 73cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Sitātapatrā accompanied by eleven buddha figures above and three deities below.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 46.0 x 33.5 cm. bordered with silk 66.5 x 47.5 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An unmounted Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Sitātapatrā surrounded by smaller human and other figures.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: A Srid-pa-ho is a Tibetan astrological divinition chart, which includes signs and symbols of the universe.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 55 x 46 cm. bordered with silk brocade 110 x 79 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts a Srid-pa-ho. The central figure is a large golden tortoise, representing the Bodhisattva of Knowledge, upon whom are drawn various geomantic diagrams, representing the nine magic squares and symbols of the eight planets.
The tanka includes a silk cover.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 52 x 32 cm., unmounted and unbordered

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased in Nepal by Ann Rohrer in 1968. Gift of Ann Rohrer, 1976.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan painting of a Srid-pa-ho, which includes a giant golden turtle and twelve animals, as well as Avalokiteśvara, Manjushri, and Vajrapāṇi, known as the Three Family Protectors.
Inscription in Tibetan on verso.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Srid-pa'i-'khor-lo, also known as bhavacakra or wheel of existence/life, is a symbolic representation of samsāra (or cyclical existence).

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 119.5 x 86.5 cm. mounted on silk brocade 176 x 102 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan painting of a Srid-pa'i-'khor-lo held by Yama, also known as Gshin.rje, the prime mover of samsāra, below Gautama Buddha in the upper right corner.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: A stupa is a dome-shaped monument housing relics of Buddha or an accomplished master.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 32.5 x 21.0 cm. bordered with silk 59 x 34 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased in Nepal by Ann Rohrer in 1968. Gift of Ann Rohrer, 1976.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Nepalese or western Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts a stupa.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Tārā, also known as Ārya Tārā or Jetsun Dolma, is a female Bodhisattva that represents the virtues of success in work and achievements

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 90.0 x 63.5 cm. bordered with silk brocade 175 x 104 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Edwin R. Meiss (Yale 1933) and Jean Hoffheimer Meiss, 1961.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Tārā surrounded by 321 miniature replica emanations of herself, as well as two incarnations of the Amitābha and Amitāyus.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 63 x 44 cm. bordered with silk 94 x 66 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts a green Tārā surrounded by miniature scenes and figures.
The tanka includes a silk cover.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 79 x 56 cm. bordered with silk brocade 158 x 88 cm

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts a white Tārā accompanied by four figures above in clouds.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Tsoṅ-kha-pa Blo-bzaṅ-grags-pa (1357-1419), also known as Tsongkhapa, was a teacher of Tibetan Buddhism and founder of the Dge-lugs-pa school of Buddhism, also known as the Yellow Hat sect.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 55 x 39 cm. bordered with silk brocade 69 x 86 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Joseph F. Weiler and Eliza Weiler, 1974.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Tsoṅ-kha-pa Blo-bzaṅ-grags-pa accompanied by two disciples.
The tanka includes a silk cover and ribbons.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 68 x 48 cm. bordered with silk brocade 139 x 73 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased in New Delhi, India, by Wesley E. Needham, 1966.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Tsoṅ-kha-pa Blo-bzaṅ-grags-pa accompanied by two disciples.
Inscriptions in Tibetan on verso.
The tanka includes a silk cover and ribbons.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 51.0 x 35.5 cm. in a frame 54 x 38 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred from the Yale University Art Gallery, 1960. Former Art Gallery No. 1952.40.22.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Tsoṅ-kha-pa Blo-bzaṅ-grags-pa surrounded by miniature figures.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Vajrabhairava, also known as Yamāntaka, a wrathful manifestation of Mañjuśrī, the bodhisattva of wisdom, and in other contexts functions as a dharmapala, or 'Dharma-protector'.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 60.5 x 41.0 cm. bordered and mounted on silk brocade 117 x 73 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A central Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Vajrabhairava with a dark blue body, nine heads, thirty-four arms, and sixteen legs, as well as wearing a garland of fifty human heads. He is below smaller figures, including Atiśa Dipankara Shrijnana (980-1054), also known as Atisha, a Buddhist teacher from the Pala Empire, and Tsoṅ-kha-pa Blo-bzaṅ-grags-pa with two disciples, as well as two protective divinities. He is above smaller figures of divinities, including Begtse, Yama, Yami, and Lha-mo.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Vajrapāṇi is a Buddhist bodhisattva and the protector and guide of Gautama Buddha.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 46.5 x 33.5 cm. bordered with silk brocade 88 x 61 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Vajrapāṇi, and includes three miniature horse heads and a garuda holding a serpant above his crown.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 66 x 52 cm. bordered with silk 104 x 76 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A western Tibetan or Nepalese watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Vajrapāṇi surrounded by eight figures.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Vajrasattva is a bodhisattva associated with the Dharmakaya and with purification practice.

did.physdesc: 1 needlework: silk on silk; 100 x 73 cm. bordered with silk 135 x 103 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. John Roger, 1973.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A central Tibetan silk appliqué on silk that depicts Vajrasattva seated on a lotus throne holding a vajra (dorje) and ghanta (bell). The mountains were likely added later by a Korean or Japanese artist.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 51 x 36 cm. bordered with silk 108 x 72 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Vajrasattva seated on a lotus holding a vajra (dorje) and ghanta (bell), below three smaller figures: a lama, Adi-Buddha, and Atiśa Dipankara Shrijnana, as well as above three protective divinities: Palden Lhamo, Mahākāla, and Yama.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Vajrayoginī is the Vajra yoginī, literally 'the diamond female yogi'. Her practice includes methods for preventing ordinary death, intermediate state (bardo) and rebirth (by transforming them into paths to enlightenment), and for transforming all mundane daily experiences into higher spiritual paths.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 61 x 38 cm. bordered with silk 90 x 55 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A western Tibetan or Nepalese watercolor painting on cotton that depicts a red Vajrayoginī drinking blood from a human skull and surrounded by many miniature figures.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 54 x 36 cm. bordered with silk brocade 63.5 x 44.5 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An unfinished Tibetan watercolor painting on cotton that depicts a red Vajrayoginī wearing a necklace skulls and drinking blood from a human skull. She is also surrounded by many miniature figures.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Vasudhārā is the Buddhist bodhisattva of wealth, prosperity, and abundance.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 65.0 x 42.5 cm. bordered with silk 117 x 90 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Nepalese watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Vasudhārā accompanied by smaller male and female divinities. The painting includes decorative elements to mimic silk brocade.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Viśrāvaṇa, also known as also known as Jambhala or the King of the North, is a worldly dharmapāla or protector of the Dharma and a god of wealth.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 89.5 x 58.0 cm. bordered with silk 137 x 82 cm

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Wendell Phillips Colton, Jr. (Yale 1929) and Cornelia Mary Safford Colton, 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Nepalese watercolor painting on cotton that depicts Viśrāvaṇa on a white horse with smaller figures on elephants, a lion, and a tiger in the four corners.
Inscriptions in Tibetan on verso.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Yungtön Dorjepel (1284-1365), also known as Gyun-ston-rdo-rje-dpal, was considered to be the final Tibetan incarnation of Amitābha Buddha before Khedrup Gelek Pelzang (1385-1438), who is recognized as the First Panchen Lama.

did.physdesc: 1 painting: watercolor on cotton; 71 x 47 cm. framed with silk 124 x 68 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Tibetan painting of Yungtön Dorjepel wearing a red hat, with smaller figures of his teacher, three disciples and divinities.
The tanka includes a silk cover.
